node.title: The Novel that Riveted France During Lockdown Arrives in the U.S.
node.alt: “I am surprised by the book’s success given that it’s so experimental, bizarre and a little crazy,” Hervé Le Tellier said of “The Anomaly,” which is his first novel to make best-seller lists.
node.description: “The Anomaly,” by Hervé Le Tellier, sold more than a million copies during an anomalous time. Now the genre-bending novel is translated into English.
node.content: ["PARIS \u2014 An Air France flight from Paris to New York lands on March 10, 2021, after passing through a terrifying storm. One hundred and six days later, the same Boeing 787 flight with the same crew, the same passengers and the same damage from an identical storm approaches the east coast of the United States. It\u2019s impossible \u2014 the passengers and crew must be doubles \u2014 and yet.", "This is the crux of \u201cThe Anomaly,\u201d a novel by Herv\u00e9 Le Tellier that has become a French literary phenomenon, and is being released in translation in the United States by Other Press on Tuesday.", "France takes its books seriously. Author photographs advertising their latest works line the streets of Paris. Bookstores are everywhere. The Prix Goncourt, the country\u2019s most prestigious literary prize, is a major annual event.", "Even so, \u201cThe Anomaly\u201d is an outlier. Published in the late summer of 2020, the novel has sold 1.1 million copies here, more than any book since Marguerite Duras\u2019s \u201cThe Lover,\u201d which came out in 1984. In an anomalous time, when a deserted Paris was in lockdown for months, and much of life moved online, the novel struck a powerful chord by suggesting the flimsiness of all we take for granted, what T.S. Eliot called \u201cthe old dispensation.\u201d", "A year ago, the novel won the 2020 Goncourt, which always boosts sales, but then something unusual happened: It kept selling. Initially, Le Tellier\u2019s editor thought he had chosen \u201ca bad title.\u201d Speaking in his cluttered Montmartre apartment, the author agreed that \u201cThe Anomaly\u201d was \u201ca flat title, even if it\u2019s a pretty word.\u201d", "Yet in the end the double anomaly at the heart of the novel \u2014 the upending of time in a world that discovers it is simulated \u2014 captured a moment when the pandemic stopped the world and existence veered toward the virtual.", "\u201cI am surprised by the book\u2019s success given that it\u2019s so experimental, bizarre and a little crazy,\u201d Le Tellier, 64, whose more than two dozen previous works never made best-seller lists, said. \u201cPerhaps reading it was a means of escape.\u201d", "The novel, which was translated into English by Adriana Hunter, begins with the description of several seemingly unrelated characters: a ruthless contract killer named Blake; an architect called Andr\u00e9 Vannier, whose girlfriend Lucie Bogaert, a movie editor, is about half his age and has lost interest in him; a down-on-his-luck novelist, Victor Miesel, who, in one of Le Tellier\u2019s many literary artifices, provides the epigraph for the novel, \u201cA true pessimist knows it is already too late to be one.\u201d", "The link between them, and the other characters who emerge, is gradually revealed. They were all on the March Air France flight. When the June flight approaches, it is diverted by U.S. authorities to an Air Force base in New Jersey and held there. As an M.I.T.-trained mathematician tells a military officer about to address the 243 bewildered passengers: \u201cI don\u2019t recommend you tell them that they all already exist in duplicate somewhere in the world and they darn well shouldn\u2019t be on this earth at all.\u201d", "The mathematician, Tina Brewster-Wang, compares the situation to being asked the possible outcomes of flipping a coin. Heads, tails and the remote chance of the coin resting on its side. But what, she adds, \u201cif the flipped coin stays suspended in the air?\u201d", "Le Tellier said he has long been fascinated by the idea of the double, a theme also taken up in literature by Fyodor Dostoyevsky, Oscar Wilde and Jorge Luis Borges. Returning home one evening, he thought: \u201cIt would be interesting if I found my double awaiting me. How would I react?\u201d This was the genesis of a book he took one year to write.", "\u201cAnd so, I inverted the usual approach in a novel, where you invent a character and plunge that character into a situation,\u201d he said. \u201cInstead, I took the situation as my starting point, one that would allow me to confront seven or eight characters with their doubles, after 106 days have elapsed. A lot can happen in 106 days! How would different characters react?\u201d", "When asked if he has ever met a doppelg\u00e4nger of his own, Le Tellier said that once, when he was crossing the Boulevard St. Germain, an older man stopped him. \u201cWe know each other,\u201d the man said to Le Tellier. \u201cI know you because I saw you in the mirror 20 years ago.\u201d", "Le Tellier is a mild-mannered man who worked briefly as a college math teacher before taking up scientific journalism and starting to write novels in his 30s. In his writing, he is interested in probability, paradox, word play. Part of the appeal of \u201cThe Anomaly\u201d is that it swerves between various genres \u2014 science fiction, a thriller, love stories, an introspective work \u2014 without being confined by any of them. It pokes fun at itself. It should be no surprise that Miesel, the novelist, is writing a novel called \u201cThe Anomaly,\u201d or that another of his epigraphs holds that the one thing that surpasses genius \u201cis incomprehension.\u201d", "Literary constraints fascinate Le Tellier. The constraint of writing without using a certain letter, \u201cu,\u201d for example. Or, in another exercise invented by the French novelist Georges Perec, writing a poem to a loved one using only the letters of the person\u2019s name. \u201cThe constraint causes something unforeseen, unanticipated, to happen,\u201d he said. Constraint, in other words, can be liberating.", "In \u201cThe Anomaly,\u201d Le Tellier described his constraints as \u201cexposition, explanation and confrontations,\u201d each addressed in one of the book\u2019s three parts. The explanation for the identical June flight was not easy, causing him a brief writer\u2019s block. Then an idea came to him: \u201cthat the world is perhaps simulated and that we are, on a biological level, nonexistent.\u201d As one of the characters observes, Descartes\u2019s \u201cI think therefore I am,\u201d is therefore obsolete, replaced by \u201cI think therefore I\u2019m almost certainly a program.\u201d", "But are 21st-century humans really just perfected algorithms? \u201cWell, we know we will get to that point,\u201d Le Tellier said. \u201cAnd if we know that, we can ask ourselves the question of whether we have not already reached it. That it\u2019s already done, and we are in fact in a simulation without knowing we are in a simulation.\u201d He smiled. \u201cI find that a rather beautiful thing.\u201d", "In the novel, a logician named Arch Wesley is tasked with explaining what is happening to the American president. He is met with an angry response. \u201cWhat you\u2019re describing is ridiculous,\u201d the president explodes. \u201cI\u2019m not some super Mario and I\u2019m certainly not about to explain to the American people that they\u2019re programs in a virtual world.\u201d", "Unfazed, Wesley suggests the second plane may constitute some sort of test that it\u2019s important for the president to pass. \u201cBecause if we fail, the entities running this simulation could just shut it down.\u201d", "Before any end of days, there are deeply human issues, which are addressed in the \u201cconfrontations\u201d between passengers and their doubles that make up the last part of the book.", "For characters like Blake, who make a living by killing, the question of who lives on is quickly and brutally resolved; for others, like a young lawyer called Joanna Wasserman who discovers that her double has gotten pregnant during the 106-day interlude, the answer is agonizing.", "\u201cIn the end, the essential question for all the characters, the only question, is what do I do with my love?\u201d Le Tellier said. \u201cLove is the point at which all the characters stumble, where they are fragile, and where they have to decide. On all the rest, they can negotiate.\u201d Because part of love is possessiveness, and that is complicated when one becomes two.", "\u201cSo, in some instances, the love has to be broken,\u201d he continued. \u201cOr the result will be an ambiguity that is cruel or an ambivalence that may even be destructive.\u201d", "The world, too, is facing agonizing decisions, Le Tellier said. The English translation of the novel arrives as world leaders have just recommitted in Glasgow to fighting global warming. The author sees climate change as an imminent threat to which the response has been paltry. \u201cThe simulation is waiting for a reaction from the entire human race,\u201d he writes in the novel. \u201cThere won\u2019t be a supreme savior. We need to save ourselves.\u201d", "The alternative, as \u201cThe Anomaly\u201d makes clear, is that whoever controls the simulation will lose patience and, in an instant, bring down the curtain."]
